dt: {bc}to enter into or take a part in the concerns of others
{bc}to {a_link|interpose} in a way that hinders or impedes {bc}come into collision or be in opposition
{bc}to strike one foot against the opposite foot or ankle in walking or running
{bc}to act reciprocally so as to augment, diminish, or otherwise affect one another

pt: {sc}interpose{/sc} {sc}interfere{/sc} {sc}intervene{/sc} {sc}mediate{/sc} {sc}intercede{/sc} mean to come or go between. {sc}interpose{/sc} often implies no more than this.

pt.t: {it}interposed{/it} herself between him and the door

pt: {sc}intervene{/sc} may imply an occurring in space or time between two things or a stepping in to stop a conflict.
{sc}intercede{/sc} implies acting for an offender in begging mercy or forgiveness.

et: Middle English {it}enterferen{/it}, from Anglo-French ({it}s'{/it}){it}entreferir{/it} to strike one another, from {it}entre-{/it} inter- + {it}ferir{/it} to strike, from Latin {it}ferire{/it} {ma}{mat|bore|}{/ma}
shortdef: to enter into or take a part in the concerns of others
to interpose in a way that hinders or impedes : come into collision or be in opposition
to strike one foot against the opposite foot or ankle in walking or running —used especially of horses

dt: {bc}to stop or slow (something) {bc}to make (something) slower or more difficult

dt.t: The drug might {it}interfere with{/it} a child's physical development.
All of the noise was {it}interfering with{/it} my concentration.

dt: {bc}to touch (a child) in a sexual and improper way

shortdef: to stop or slow (something) : to make (something) slower or more difficult
to touch (a child) in a sexual and improper way
